en: Interview with Bill May, 2019-10-14

Interview with Bill May, executive director for Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts. May gives an overview of the history of Gatlinburg and particularly how Arrowmont has been involved in the region since its founding. He recounts the day of the fire in regards to the suddeness of the disaster and his efforts at the school. He also discusses the community activity centered at Arrowmont during following the wildfire. This is a representative quote from the interview: "That will always color my impression of the fires. It happened to people, and it happened to people regardless of station, regardless of financial circumstances."

Interview Questions
Can you tell us about how long you have been in Gatlinburg?
Where were you before moving to Gatlinburg?
What has your life here been like and how were you involved with the community?
How has Gatlinburg changed since you've been here?
Can you tell us about Arrowmont and how it has evolved?
Can you tell us about the programs offered by Arrowmont?
Can you tell us about the days leading up to the fires?
Was there fear amongs the students and artists in residence?
Was your wife still at home or had she already left?
About what time did you leave campus and head home?
Why do you think that the news reported the school had burned?
How do you feel that social media played a role through the fire?
What were the following days like when people started returning to campus?
Have you seen art used as a form of healing since the wildfires?
Do you think tourists coming through Gatlinburg today have any idea about what happened in 2016?
Have you thought about any provisions going forward in case of a similar emergency?
Has anything good or sursprising come out of this?
Is there anything else that you would like to add?
